text: Jon hop again hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new John Hopkins album
immunity John Hopkins is a london-based
electronic music producer
this is his second full-length solo LP
for Domino Records I first heard of his
music after he signed to Domino Records
and put out his first full-length for
them insides back in 2009 and album I
liked a lot of tracks from especially
songs like the very heavy crushing and
kind of distorted title track and a lot
of the other songs on this thing - which
had very eerie beautiful and kind of
cinematic synth playing throughout at
the end of the day I just felt like the
album was okay though because it really
felt like a mixed bag of ideas from IDM
downtempo glitch even though I did like
a lot of tracks off of insides I I
didn't think John Hopkins would come
back around and put out an LP I enjoy
this much the mmunity pulls together a
lot of tracks that are various blends of
house and techno styles occasionally
John will come through with his very
cinematic ear which will lead him to
introduce some very spacious beautiful
piano chords it's almost as if he's
doing a modern minimal neoclassical
thing against some of these electronic
sounds and I have to say as far as tech
house goes John's blends of these styles
are really good on this thing of course
you've got a lot of driving quarter-note
kick drums as far as the grooves go this
album is is not very robotic cold or
chilly but I wouldn't exactly say this
LP is bouncy or lively either rather
what John is pulling together with these
tracks is something that is very
textured kind of glitchy really dramatic
and there's a very strong melodic
element to these tracks too even if it
is a very soft and spacious once-once
one John's beats can be really thick and
just dense with different sounds but he
keeps it rather simple when it comes to
the melody writing which is okay he does
sort of do a quality over quantity kind
of thing
doesn't really busy up a lot of these
leads and and still even though they
aren't really in your face and they do
take their time to grow and progress
they are very pretty
gripping even though a lot of what
you'll hear on this album if you try it
out are repetitive beats repetitive
loops that progress very subtly John
with the way he arranges piano and sense
and just other sounds around these
grooves it makes them feel so purposeful
and lofty and kind of poignant without
him even really saying anything on these
songs this loftiness and sense of
purpose really progresses to the point
where the last track on this LP with
these really faint vocals and these
beautiful spacious pianos they sound
like they're from a cut from the last
cigarette it's not a bad track but it is
one of the few moments on this LP that
to me feel kind of just out of place
really come in at a left-field still the
more electronically driven tracks that
John pulls together on this thing are
high-quality the opening track on here
has this amazing beat that is just dark
it's subtle but very dense it's
simultaneously noisy and quiet it's just
so friggin textured I love it the murky
bass line on this thing is fantastic the
atmospheric synthesizers on this thing
and I love that this song the way it
ends it almost feels like I'm just
gliding into the next track there's not
some breaking point like okay this is a
totally different thing than this job
really holistically conceives this album
after this you've got tracks like open
high signal as well as Collider songs
that in my opinion take a stronger
techno approach the hard beats on these
tracks feel mechanical calculated but
both of these songs are still incredibly
detailed and Atmospheric the track open
I signal with its constant beat change
ups and it's bass line which I cannot
even explain I mean not melodically
melodically it's actually pretty simple
but what he does with it texturally it
feels like he wrote this really smooth
bouncy bass line and he's just like
choking it and shaking it just there are
moments where it's really deep and
resonant
and thick
and then there are other spots where it
feels like he's just crushing and
squeezing it to get these very strange
melodic undertones and the song Collider
takes a little bit of a different
approach with its beat it's not always
changing up it's actually pretty
hypnotic and very very repetitive but
the sounds that John arranges around
this track especially the really
atmospheric sense it's almost deafening
how thick this track gets the more piano
driven pieces are beautiful beauty-full
and had a fantastic counterpoint to the
more electronic tracks on this LP I
think the only song that I didn't really
care for was the track formed by
firelight with this really slow kind of
distorted shuffling beat that didn't
really appeal to me all that much a lot
of John's piano playing around this beat
is is very pretty as it is on previous
tracks but with the relief arty-farty
bass line on this thing that just felt
really flat and just kind of bodyless
there were a lot of reasons I just
wasn't digging the sounds on this thing
because of that track and and the closer
like I said whose sound really kind of
comes out of nowhere for me this LP does
fall apart a little bit at the end but a
majority of this album I'm telling you
it's it's it's very long stretch out
tech house tracks that lasts 7 9 12
minutes and these lengthy giants as well
as these smaller piano driven pieces
around them I'm loving them I'm feeling
a light decent 8 on this LP if you've
given it a listen what do you think did
you love it hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
this review is my opinion if you don't
like it here's a straw I want to give a
shout out to John Smith who made this
picture Edward Snowden and the NSA
remember you're being tapped my dad and
the Kanye review which is coming up next
okay all right only the strong subscribe
all mistakes were intentional Anthony
Fantana John Hopkins
forever
[Music]
you
